title: Donald Trump's decision to withdraw US troops from Syria 'jeopardised' Baghdadi mission
text:
President Trump's abrupt decision to withdraw US troops from Syria disrupted the planning of the raid on ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi's compound, military officials warned.

Despite knowing intelligence services were closing in on a location for Baghdadi, the president still ordered US troops to be withdrawn from the volatile region of northern Syria earlier this month, officials claimed.

Pentagon advisers warned the president against making major changes on the ground in Syria as neutralising the militant leader was a top priority, the New York Times reports.

Trump's sudden move to vacate northern Syria threw the region into turmoil, leaving Turkey free to invade across the border and target US Kurdish allies, who fought to push ISIS from their so-called caliphate, established by Baghdadi in 2014.

President Trump speaking in the Diplomatic Room of the White House in Washington, on the death of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi during a US military raid in Syria yesterday

Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi being interviewed by his group's Al-Furqan media outlet in April when he emerged after months of speculation about his whereabouts

This pullout 'complicated' the mission to catch Baghdadi and the raid 'occurred largely in spite of, and not because of, Mr Trump's actions', US officials told the Times.

It meant the US had to stay in contact with Russia and Turkey in order for the special forces helicopters to fly over the skies of northern Syria and target the ISIS leader's hideout.

US operators were also forced to rush the mission as they lost control of the airspace in the crucial area, sources claimed.

Baghdadi detonated a suicide belt as Delta Force commandos stormed his compound in the village of Barisha near Idlib, northern Syria on Saturday.

The operation came four days after Trump green lit the raid, with the president cryptically tweeting before the mission was announced: 'Something very big has just happened!'

Even though the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) felt abandoned by the US as they sought the help of President Bashar al-Assad and his Russian troops, the Kurds still reportedly provided information to the CIA on Baghdadi's location after the withdrawal.

US soldiers in armoured personnel carriers as American forces pulled out of their base in the northern Syrian town of Tal Tamr last week

President Donald Trump watching in the Situation Room as US Special Operations forces close in on ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi on Saturday

Intelligence on his whereabouts also came from Iraqi forces who captured members of Baghdadi's inner circle, including his courier and the courier's wife, according to the Telegraph.

In front of a news conference yesterday, the president touted the operation and Baghdadi's death as 'bigger than bin Laden'.

He said Baghdadi died 'whimpering and crying and screaming', and 'like a dog and a coward'.

Osama bin Laden, founder of Al-Qaeda and the terrorist leader behind the September 11 terrorist attacks, was killed in 2011 during a Navy SEALs operation during Barack Obama's presidency.

The compound was destroyed in a US helicopter raid while Baghdadi fled into a tunnel, then detonated an explosive belt, killing himself and three of his children

Trump also divulged sensitive operational details to the media, the military sources also said.

The president added: 'He reached the end of the tunnel as our dogs chased him down. He ignited his vest, killing himself and the three children.

'His body was mutilated by the blast. the tunnel had caved in on it, in addition. But test results gave certain, immediate and totally positive identification.

'It was him. The thug who tried so hard to intimidate others spent his last moments in utter fear, in total panic and dread, terrified of the American forces bearing down on him.'

The president confirmed yesterday, Baghdadi detonated his suicide vest after fleeing into a dead-end tunnel, killing himself and three children, during an overnight targeted attack.
description: Despite knowing US intelligence was closing in on a location for Baghdadi, President Trump still ordered US troops to be withdrawn from the volatile region of northern Syria earlier this month.
